ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Asynchronous exams that could be started at any point during the day and lasted a previously specified amount of time.
Live virtual discussions (once a week with professor, once a week with Teaching Assistant)

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Significant improvements in typing, reading, speaking, and listening Chinese.

I learned how to better read and write Chinese and also improved my speaking performance. There's a LOT more writing in L3 than in L1/L2, but it wasn't overwhelming (at least for me). It was really helpful in improving my writing ability and testing how far my Chinese could go!
My knowledge of Mandarin Chinese vocabulary and grammar patterns increased. My speaking and writing abilities also improved.

My Chinese skills, especially speaking improvisation skills, improved by a large margin. This was thanks to the oral projects, presentations, and 1-on-1 speaking tutorials that the class emphasized alongside more traditional forms of learning like textbook problems and reading dialogues.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The only aspect I did not improve in significantly was my handwriting skills, mainly due to the online format of examinations. However, we still were able to get some practice in the form of handwriting our essays. Other than that, all of the homework was well spread-out such that I never felt particularly overwhelmed by its work at any point in the semester. The nightly assignments took about an hour each, so we got lots of practice in and I was able to still improve.

Strengths: Wang Laoshi is amazing. She's amazing. I love her so much. 
Weaknesses: It is going to be a lot of work, but language classes are always a lot of work, and Chinese isn't an exception.

Strengths: The setup of the daily schedule was incredibly convenient. Because the class meets every day, it was useful to have a visual that informed me what homework was due each day. I was also able to work ahead when I had the chance.

Weaknesses: This isn't a weakness per se, but the virtual format required adapting to a lot of new technologies. Also, the dependency on Zoom- and, therefore, Zoom's stability- made participation especially difficult. Because I can't whisper to another classmate or outright ask another classmate for help in the virtual environment, my learning comes entirely from the professor. Perhaps increased utilization of break-out rooms would be useful. Additionally, Zoom was unkind to my camera the entire semester, so I was not able to participate as well as I would have liked to, or I had to overcompensate and constantly answer questions because the professor would be less likely to call on me without my face being visible. (This is no fault of the professor in my opinion, and entirely the "fault" of the class format due to COVID.) Lastly, the virtual format, the accelerated speed of the class, and the amount of homework meant that a lot of assignments that we completed were not checked during class time. We did not correct any Reading or Listening assignments, and I had many questions on these assignments, but I was only able to ask them in office hours, which was held at a time that did not work for my schedule.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This was overall an amazing class despite the Zoom format!

The course was incredibly well-structured. It was very clear what we had to do every day for homework, there were minimal technical difficulties, and surprisingly, I still learned a lot of Chinese despite the circumstances, although of course it would've been nice to be in an in-person classroom setting. I think something really important is that Wang Laoshi really cares for her students, not just as academics but also as people. I don't think any other professor has ever been as understanding and kind to me this whole seemster.

The virtual format required adapting to a lot of new technologies. Also, the dependency on Zoom- and, therefore, Zoom's stability- made participation especially difficult. Because I can't whisper to another classmate or outright ask another classmate for help in the virtual environment, my learning comes entirely from the professor. Perhaps increased utilization of break-out rooms would be useful. Additionally, Zoom was unkind to my camera the entire semester, so I was not able to participate as well as I would have liked to, or I had to overcompensate and constantly answer questions because the professor would be less likely to call on me without my face being visible. (This is no fault of the professor in my opinion, and entirely the "fault" of the class format due to COVID.)
Office hours were also a challenge. Because the one time my professor held office hours were inconvenient for me, I was unable to meet with her more often throughout the semester. I would like to recommend that professors try to offer office hours on two different days of the week.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely yes! This course was well-structured, engaging, and improved my Chinese skills by leaps and bounds.
Yes, yes, yes, yes. Language learning is the only thing that gives me joy these days. So yes, take this course.
Definitely! I absolutely love Chinese because of the amazing courses offered here. Despite a high workload, it is a great payoff and very very fun!

I would recommend this course regardless, but I would be more inclined to recommend this course if my above suggestions were included. This is the first semester of the second year of Chinese language, it is meant to be intensive, and the content is imperative to gaining fluency in Mandarin Chinese.

If you're ready for Chinese L3, then you should definitely take the course! The teachers are all very eager to help students improve their Chinese, and the assignments were surprisingly fun even while they helped you practice the concepts and vocabulary in the textbook.
